Question: PFA-001 - Compared to trailing edge flaps, leading edge devices like Slots...
Option A: reduce the critical angle of attack at a given speed.
Option B: allow higher speeds at take-off and landing.
Option C: produce less drag while allowing a higher angle of attack.
Option D: increase the camber and allow a lower angle of attack.
Answer: produce less drag while allowing a higher angle of attack.

Question: PFA-002 - Stabilization around the lateral axis during cruise is achieved by the...
PFA-003 - Flying with speeds higher than the never-exceed-speed (vNE) may result in...
Option A: too high total pressure resulting in an unusable airspeed indicator.
Option B: flutter and mechanically damaging the wings.
Option C: an increased lift-to-drag ratio and a better glide angle.
Option D: reduced drag with increased control forces.
Answer: flutter and mechanically damaging the wings.

Question: PFA-004 - What effects typically result from propeller icing?
PFA-005 - During a straight and steady climb, which force acts additionally, and in the same direction as the drag force, resulting in more power required for climb than for horizontal flight?
Option A: A component of the weight force along the rearward flight path.
Option B: The vertical component of the weight force.
Option C: A component of the thrust along the rearward flightpath.
Option D: A component of the lift force along the forward flightpath.
Answer: A component of the weight force along the rearward flight path.

Question: PFA-006 - The static pressure of gases work...
Option A: only vertical to the flow direction.
Option B: only in the direction of the total pressure.

Question: PFA-007 - Bernoulli's equation for frictionless, incompressible gases states that...
Option A: static pressure = total pressure + dynamic pressure.
Option B: total pressure = dynamic pressure - static pressure.
Option C: dynamic pressure = total pressure + static pressure.
Option D: total pressure = dynamic pressure + static pressure.
Answer: total pressure = dynamic pressure + static pressure.

Question: PFA-008 - If surrounded by airflow (v>0), any arbitrarily shaped body produces...
PFA-009 - All aerodynamic forces can be considered to act on a single point. This point is called...
PFA-010 - The center of pressure is the theoretical point of origin of...
Option B: all aerodynamic forces of the profile.
Answer: all aerodynamic forces of the profile.

Question: PFA-011 - Number 2 in the drawing corresponds to the...
PFA-012 - Number 3 in the drawing corresponds to the...
PFA-013 - The angle of attack is the angle between...
Option A: the undisturbed airflow and the longitudinal axis of an aeroplane.
Option B: the chord line and the longitudinal axis of an aeroplane.
Option C: the chord line and the oncoming airflow.
Option D: the wing and the fuselage of an aeroplane.
Answer: the chord line and the oncoming airflow.

Question: PFA-014 - The ratio of span and mean chord length is referred to as...

PFA-016 - Which point on the aerofoil is represented by number 4?
PFA-017 - Wing tip vortex development begins during which phase of flight?
Option A: As soon as the aircraft starts moving
Option B: While setting take-off power during take-off run
Option C: While setting flaps to lower position
Option D: When lift is being generated during rotation
Answer: When lift is being generated during rotation

Question: PFA-018 - Which point on the aerofoil is represented by number 1?
PFA-019 - What pattern can be found at the stagnation point?
Option A: The boundary layer starts separating on the upper surface of the profile
Option B: The laminar boundary layer changes into a turbulent boundary layer
Option C: All aerodynamic forces can be considered as attacking at this single point
Option D: Streamlines are divided into airflow above and below the profile
Answer: Streamlines are divided into airflow above and below the profile

Question: PFA-020 - What pressure pattern can be observed at a lift-generating wing profile at positive angle of attack?
Option A: Low pressure is created above, higher pressure below the profile
Option B: High pressure is created above, lower pressure below the profile
Option C: Pressure above remains unchanged, higher pressure is created below the profile
Option D: Pressure below remains unchanged, lower pressure is created above the profile
Answer: Low pressure is created above, higher pressure below the profile

Question: PFA-021 - The position of the center of pressure at a positively shaped profile...
Option A: moves to the leading edge while the angle of attack becomes smaller.
Option B: is located at approximately 25% of the chord, measured from the leading edge.
Option C: moves to the trailing edge while the angle of attack becomes smaller.
Option D: does not move since it is independent of the angle of attack.
Answer: moves to the trailing edge while the angle of attack becomes smaller.

Question: PFA-022 - In which way does the position of the center of pressure move at a positively shaped profile with increasing angle of attack?
Option A: It moves backward until reaching the critical angle of attack
Option B: It moves forward first, then backward
Option C: It moves forward until reaching the critical angle of attack
Option D: It moves to the wing tips
Answer: It moves forward until reaching the critical angle of attack

Question: PFA-023 - Which statement about lift and angle of attack is correct?
Option A: Too large angles of attack can lead to an exponential increase in lift
Option B: Increasing the angle of attack results in less lift being generated by the aerofoil
Option C: Increasing the angle of attack too far may result in a loss of lift and an airflow separation
Option D: Decreasing the angle of attack results in more drag being generated by the aerofoil
Answer: Increasing the angle of attack too far may result in a loss of lift and an airflow separation

Question: PFA-024 - Which statement about the airflow around an aerofoil is correct if the angle of attack increases?
Option B: The center of pressure moves down
Option C: The center of pressure moves up

Question: PFA-025 - Which statement about the airflow around an aerofoil is correct if the angle of attack decreases?
Option A: The center of pressure moves aft
Option D: The center of pressure moves forward
Answer: The center of pressure moves aft

Question: PFA-026 - The angle (alpha) shown in the figure is referred to as...
PFA-027 - In order to improve the stall characteristics of an aircraft, the wing is twisted outwards (the angle of incidence varies spanwise). This is known as...
PFA-028 - Which option states a benefit of wing washout?
Option A: Structurally the wing is made more rigid against rotation
Option B: With the washout the form drag reduces at high speeds
Option C: Greater hardness because the wing can withstand more torsion forces
Option D: At high angles of attack the effectiveness of the aileron is retained as long as possible
Answer: At high angles of attack the effectiveness of the aileron is retained as long as possible

Question: PFA-029 - Which statement concerning the angle of attack is correct?
Option A: The angle of attack cannot be negative
Option B: Increasing the angle of attack results in decreasing lift
Option C: The angle of attack is constant throughout the flight
Option D: A too large angle of attack may result in a loss of lift
Answer: A too large angle of attack may result in a loss of lift

Question: PFA-030 - When increasing the airflow speed by a factor of 2 while keeping all other parameters constant, how does the parasite drag change approximately?
Option A: It decreases by a factor of 2
Option B: It increases by a factor of 2
Option C: It decreases by a factor of 4
Option D: It increases by a factor of 4
Answer: It increases by a factor of 4

Question: PFA-031 - The drag coefficient...
Option B: is proportional to the lift coefficient.
Option C: cannot be lower than a non-negative, minimal value.
Option D: may range from zero to an infinite positive value.
Answer: cannot be lower than a non-negative, minimal value.

Option D: the outer part of the ailerons.

Option A: Induced drag decreases and parasite drag increases

Option C: Parasite drag decreases and induced drag decreases
Option D: Induced drag increases and parasite drag increases
Answer: Induced drag decreases and parasite drag increases

Question: PFA-042 - Which statement about induced drag during the horizontal cruise flight is correct?
Option A: Induced drag has a minimum at a certain speed and increases at higher as well as lower speeds
Option B: Induced drag has a maximum at a certain speed and decreases at higher as well as lower speeds
Option C: Induced drag increases with increasing airspeed
Option D: Induced drag decreases with increasing airspeed
Answer: Induced drag decreases with increasing airspeed

Question: PFA-043 - In which mentioned situation is the total drag at its minimum?
Option A: Induced drag is twice as much as parasite drag
Option B: Parasite drag is twice as much as induced drag
Option C: Parasite drag is equal to induced drag
Option D: Induced drag is smaller than parasite drag
Answer: Parasite drag is equal to induced drag

Question: PFA-044 - Which kinds of drag contribute to total drag?
Option A: Form drag, skin-friction drag, interference drag
Option C: Induced drag, form drag, skin-friction drag

Question: PFA-045 - How do lift and drag change when approaching a stall condition?
PFA-046 - In case of a stall it is important to...
Option A: increase the bank angle and reduce the speed.
Option B: increase the angle of attack and increase the speed.
Option C: decrease the angle of attack and increase the speed.
Option D: increase the angle of attack and reduce the speed.
Answer: decrease the angle of attack and increase the speed.

Question: PFA-047 - During a stall, the lift...
PFA-048 - The critical angle of attack...
Option B: decreases with forward center of gravity position.
Option D: increases with backward center of gravity position.

PFA-051 - In motorplanes the stall warning is usually activated by a change of...

Option D: Raise the nose to decrease airspeed

Question: PFA-053 - Which statement regarding a spin is correct?
Option A: During recovery the ailerons should be kept neutral
Option B: Only very old aeroplanes have a risk of spinning
Option C: During recovery the ailerons should be crossed
Option D: During the spin the speed constantly increases
Answer: During recovery the ailerons should be kept neutral

Question: PFA-054 - When extending the flaps for landing at constant angle of attack, in which way does the lift coefficient change far before reaching the maximum lift coefficient?
Option B: It is not possible to define

Question: PFA-055 - With regard to flaps, which of the following options provides a lift-increasing effect?
PFA-056 - Which factor can be changed by deploying flaps for landing?
Option A: The position of the center of gravity
Option C: The twist effect of the engine

Question: PFA-057 - What is the principle of a Fowler flap?
Option A: A profile-like flap is extended from the trailing edge of the wing
Option B: A flap from the rear bottom side of the wing is folded down
Option C: At high angles of attack a part of the leading edge lifts
Option D: The rear part of the wing is folded down
Answer: A profile-like flap is extended from the trailing edge of the wing

Question: PFA-058 - A take-off with flaps in take-off position causes...
Option C: a shortening of the take-off run.
Answer: a shortening of the take-off run.

Question: PFA-059 - Provided that no other procedure is described in the Aircraft Operating Handbook, after increasing the engine power in a go-around, the flaps may...
Option A: not be operated up to the minimum safe altitude.
Option B: be retracted to a middle position.
Option C: be fully retracted without any delay.
Option D: remain fully extended until reaching the traffic pattern.
Answer: be retracted to a middle position.

Question: PFA-060 - How do lift and drag change when setting flaps to a lower position?
PFA-061 - The laminar boundary layer on the aerofoil is located between...
Option A: the transition point and the separation point.
Option B: the stagnation point and the transition point.
Option C: the transition point and the center of pressure.
Option D: the stagnation point and the center of pressure.
Answer: the stagnation point and the transition point.

Question: PFA-062 - What types of boundary layers can be found on an aerofoil?
Option A: Laminar layer at the leading wing areas, turbulent boundary layer at the trailing areas
Option B: Turbulent boundary layer along the complete upper surface with separated airflow
Option C: Turbulent layer at the leading wing areas, laminar boundary layer at the trailing areas
Option D: Laminar boundary layer along the complete upper surface with non-separated airflow
Answer: Laminar layer at the leading wing areas, turbulent boundary layer at the trailing areas

Question: PFA-063 - How does a laminar boundary layer differ from a turbulent boundary layer?
Option A: The laminar boundary layer produces lift, the turbulent boundary layer produces drag
Option B: The turbulent boundary layer is thicker and provides less skin-friction drag
Option C: The laminar boundary layer is thinner and provides more skin-friction drag
Option D: The turbulent boundary layer can follow the airfoil camber at higher angles of attack
Answer: The turbulent boundary layer can follow the airfoil camber at higher angles of attack

Question: PFA-064 - What structural item provides lateral stability to an airplane?
PFA-065 - Which statement describes a situation of static stability?
Option A: An aircraft distorted by external impact will tend to an even more deflected position
Option B: An aircraft distorted by external impact will return to the original position
Option C: An aircraft distorted by external impact can return to its original position by rudder input
Option D: An aircraft distorted by external impact will maintain the deflected position
Answer: An aircraft distorted by external impact will return to the original position

Option D: is not changed by different aircraft weights.
Answer: is not changed by different aircraft weights.

Question: PFA-073 - In straight and level flight with constant performance of the engine, the angle of attack at the wing is...

Option A: To stabilise the aeroplane around the lateral axis
Option B: To initiate a curve around the vertical axis
Option C: To stabilise the aeroplane around the longitudinal axis
Option D: To stabilise the aeroplane around the vertical axis
Answer: To stabilise the aeroplane around the lateral axis

Question: PFA-075 - The elevator deflection during take-off rotation...
Option A: is increased for a front centre of gravity.
Option B: is increased for a rear centre of gravity.
Answer: is increased for a front centre of gravity.

Question: PFA-076 - The elevator moves an aeroplane around the...

Option A: The center of gravity's position can only be determined during flight.
Option B: Only correct loading can assure a correct and safe center of gravity position.
Option C: By moving the elevator trim tab, the center of gravity can be shifted into a correct position.

Answer: Only correct loading can assure a correct and safe center of gravity position.

Question: PFA-078 - Rudder deflections result in a turn of the aeroplane around the...

Option A: pitching of the aircraft to the right.
Option B: yawing of the aircraft to the right.
Option C: yawing of the aircraft to the left.
Option D: pitching of the aircraft to the left.
Answer: yawing of the aircraft to the left.

Question: PFA-080 - What is the advantage of differential aileron movement?
Option A: The ratio of the drag coefficient to lift coefficient is increased
Option C: The drag of the downwards deflected aileron is lowered and the adverse yaw is smaller
Option D: The total lift remains constant during aileron deflection
Answer: The drag of the downwards deflected aileron is lowered and the adverse yaw is smaller

Question: PFA-081 - Which design feature can compensate for adverse yaw?
PFA-082 - Differential aileron deflection is used to...
Option B: avoid a stall at low angles of attack.

Question: PFA-083 - The right aileron deflects upwards, the left downwards. How does the aircraft react?
Option A: Rolling to the left, no yawing
Option B: Rolling to the right, yawing to the right
Option C: Rolling to the right, yawing to the left
Option D: Rolling to the left, yawing to the right
Answer: Rolling to the right, yawing to the left

Question: PFA-084 - The aerodynamic rudder balance...

Question: PFA-087 - During cruise flight with constant power setting, an aircraft shows a permanent tendency to raise the nose. How can this tendency be eliminated?
Option A: By deflecting the elevator trim tab upwards
Option B: By shifting the center of gravity backwards
Option D: By deflecting the elevator trim tab downwards
Answer: By deflecting the elevator trim tab upwards

Question: PFA-088 - The trim tab at the elevator is defelected upwards. In which position is the corresponding indicator?

Option A: The propeller keeps the airspeed constant
Option B: The pitch of the propeller rises with higher speeds
Option C: The RPM decreases with lower speeds
Option D: The set RPM is kept constant by the motor power (MAP)
Answer: The pitch of the propeller rises with higher speeds

Question: PFA-092 - The change in pitch at a propeller blade from the root to the tip ensures...
Option A: that the most thrust is produced at the blade tip.
Option B: that the most thrust is produced at the blade root.
Option C: a nearly constant load by a constant effective angle of attack over the entire length of the blade.
Option D: the largest possible angle of attack at the blade tip.
Answer: a nearly constant load by a constant effective angle of attack over the entire length of the blade.

Question: PFA-093 - After an engine failure, the windmilling propeller...
Option B: has a greater pitch in feathered position.
Option D: improves the properties of the glide.

Question: PFA-094 - During a descent at idle power with constant speed, the propeller lever is moved backwards. How do the propeller pitch and sink rate change?
Option A: Propeller pitch is increased, sink rate is increased
Option B: Propeller pitch is increased, sink rate is decreased
Option C: Propeller pitch is decreased, sink rate is increased
Option D: Propeller pitch is decreased, sink rate is decreased
Answer: Propeller pitch is increased, sink rate is decreased

Question: PFA-095 - Point number 1 in the figure indicates which flight state?
PFA-096 - Point number 5 in the figure indicates which flight state?
PFA-097 - The bank in a two-minute turn (rate one turn) depends on the...
PFA-098 - In a co-ordinated turn, how is the relation between the load factor (n) and the stall speed (Vs)?
Option A: n is smaller than 1, Vs is greater than in straight and level flight.
Option B: n is greater than 1, Vs is greater than in straight and level flight.
Option C: n is smaller than 1, Vs is smaller than in straight and level flight.
Option D: n is greater than 1, Vs is smaller than in straight and level flight.
Answer: n is greater than 1, Vs is greater than in straight and level flight.

Question: PFA-099 - How is the balance of forces affected during a turn?
Option A: Lift force must be increased to compensate for the sum of centrifugal and gravitational force
Option B: The net force results from superposition of gravity and centripetal forces
Option C: The horizontal component of the lift force during a turn is the centrifugal force
Option D: A lower lift force compensates for a lower net force as compared to level flight
Answer: Lift force must be increased to compensate for the sum of centrifugal and gravitational force

Question: PFA-100 - The pressure compensation between wind upper and lower surface results in ...
Option A: laminar airflow by wing tip vortices.
Option B: profile drag by wing tip vortices.
Option C: induced drag by wing tip vortices.
Answer: induced drag by wing tip vortices.

Question: PFA-101 - What is meant by "ground effect"?
Option A: Increase of lift and increase of induced drag close to the ground
Option B: Decrease of lift and increase of induced drag close to the ground
Option C: Decrease of lift and decrease of induced drag close to the ground
Option D: Increase of lift and decrease of induced drag close to the ground
Answer: Increase of lift and decrease of induced drag close to the ground

Question: PFA-102 - What is the diffeence between spin and spiral dive?
Option A:
Spin: stall at outer wing, speed constant;
Spiral dive: airflow at both wings, speed increasing rapidly
Option B:
Spin: stall at inner wing, speed constant;
Spiral dive: airflow at both wings, speed increasing rapidly
Option C:
Spin: stall at outer wing, speed increasing rapidly;
Spiral dive: airflow at both wings, speed constant
Option D:
Spin: stall at inner wing, speed increasing rapidly;
Spiral dive: airflow at both wings, speed constant
Answer:
Spin: stall at inner wing, speed constant;
Spiral dive: airflow at both wings, speed increasing rapidly
